Health Center Wellness
Worksite WellnessWhat is Worksite Wellness?

“An organized program in the worksite that is intended to assist employees and their family members in making voluntary behavior changes which reduce their health and injury risks, improve their health consumer skills and enhance their individual productivity and well-being.”
Wellness Council of America

Our Mission Statement:

To improve the health and well-being of BYU-Idaho employee’s lives through health education and activities that will support positive lifestyle change thereby resulting in improved employee productivity and morale.

The average BYU-Idaho employee spends about fifty percent of their waking hours at work. Consequently, departments need an active wellness program to help employees achieve a higher state of well-being.

Reasons to Engage in a Worksite Wellness Program:

  • Improve Productivity
  • Increase awareness of lifestyle related health risks
  • Reinforce positive health practices
  • Provide motivation to make behavioral changes
  • Enhance employee morale
  • Reduce stress

As part of this program, college employees will be given monthly information and incentive activities to promote wellness. The information will be conveyed through emails to a department or college secretary who will be responsible for sending it to each employee. At the end of every month, the results will be reported to a secretary and then passed on to the Wellness Coordinator.

Involvement is voluntary. However, all part-time and full-time employees will be invited to participate and will be included in potential incentives based on participation. The college would be responsible for providing their own specific incentives for participants. (i.e. t-shirts, basket of fruit, etc.)

Examples of Challenges or Activites:

  • 100,000 step challenge
  • Lazy man ironman
  • 4 week nutrition challenge

If you are interested in starting a worksite wellness program in your office or would like to know more information contact the Student Wellness Coordinator at healthcenterwellness@byui.edu
